message.content: A metonymy is a figure of speech in which something related to the whole is used to refer to the whole or a part of it. It's a type of synecdoche, where a part stands for the whole or vice versa. For example, "The White House" refers to the US presidential residence instead of the building itself; "Pennsylvania Avenue" is used to refer to the US government and its policies; "Wall Street" is used to refer to the financial industry in New York City; "the Pentagon" is used to refer to the military.
